titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Francis Gilman Blake Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:31

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of laboratory notebooks, lecture notes, patient charts, correspondence and photographs, primarily documenting the medical career of Francis Gilman Blake, including his tenure as Dean of the Yale School of Medicine and medical research. Also included is correspondence to his wife documenting his personal life.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Yale University Historical Medical Library, 1980. Gift of John B. Blake, 2006.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Francis Gilman Blake Papers (MS 1281). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Francis Gilman Blake was born on February 22, 1887, in Mansfield Valley, Pennsylvania. After his father died when he was three, his family moved to Massachusetts. He received his A.B. from Dartmouth in 1908 and spent the next year tutoring a schoolboy in Maine in order to pay for Harvard Medical School, from which he received his M.D. in 1913. For the next three years, Blake worked as an intern at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He met Dorothy P. Dewey, a nurse in training at Peter Bent Brigham, whom he married on June 1, 1916, and with whom he had three sons. Over the next few years, Blake worked as a researcher at the Rockefeller Institute and as a professor of medicine at the University of Minnesota. In 1921, he joined the faculty at the Yale School of Medicine as one of the youngest full professors of medicine in the school's history. He served as dean of the school from 1940 to 1947. His important contributions to the medical field include research in epidemic diseases and some of the first laboratory and clinical tests of penicillin. Throughout his life, Blake was associated with the government and army, serving as civil director of army medical research. He died of a heart condition at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, on February 1, 1952.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of laboratory notebooks, lecture notes, patient charts, correspondence and photographs, primarily documenting the medical career of Francis Gilman Blake, including his tenure as Dean of the Yale School of Medicine and medical research. Also included is correspondence to his wife documenting his personal life.

did.unittitle: Laboratory books, lecture notes, research material, photographs, charts, and correspondence relating to medical research
Laboratory books, lecture notes, research material, photographs, charts, and correspondence relating to medical research

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The accession has been arranged into four sections: Academic Files, Office Files, Personal Files and United States of America Typhus Commission and alphabetical by title therein.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes newspaper clippings, wedding invitation, and memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During his tour of duty with the United States Army during World War I, Blake wrote frequently to his wife about the progress of his medical research. He discussed the conditions of his medical subjects, who were drawn from "detention centers", where new recruits were quarantined to isolate any contagions they may have brought with them to the base, the flora and fauna of the region, daily life at the bases where he was stationed (including maps of the base layouts), and the conditions of the hospitals where he worked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence betwen Blake and his wife details his research while working in New Guinea.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes material on return via Singapore, Bangkok, Karachi, Cairo, and London.
